prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request CO(4-3) observations with Band 3 for a quasar at z=3.244, where the CO line is shifted to an observed frequency of 109.14 GHz. We will use a bandwidth of 1875 MHz in dual polarization mode, which is fully sufficient to detect the CO emission line with an expected width of a few 100 km/s. We set three more spectral windows with the same width for the continuum estimation. We need an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec which is comparable to the resolution in our near-infrared Adaptive Optics supported K-band imaging. To estimate the expected CO flux density, we compute an absolute B-band luminosity of 10^11.3 Lsol from our H-band imaging for a host galaxy of 10^11.2 Msol. After converting the optical magnitude into a FIR luminosity we predict a total CO flux density of about 0.75 mJy consistent with the flux densities estimated for z=6 quasar host galaxies in Wang[2013]. We request a sensistivity of 0.15 mJy per pointing which in return leads to an estimated total time request of 1.07h for this target inclusing overheads.

We request [CII] observations with Band 8 for a quasar at z=3.65, where the CII line is shifted to an observed frequency of 408.71 GHz. We will use a bandwidth of 1875 MHz in dual polarization mode, which is fully sufficient to detect the CO emission line with an expected width of a few 100 km/s. We set three more spectral windows with the same width for the continuum estimation. We need a high angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec which is comparable to the resolution in our near-infrared Adaptive Optics supported K-band imaging. To estimate the expected CII flux density, we use an upper limit on the stellar mass estimate to compute an absolute B-band luminosity. After converting the optical magnitude into a FIR luminosity we predict a total CII flux density of about 1 mJy consistent with the CII flux densities estimated for z=6 quasars in Wang[2013] with similar bolometric luminosities and BH mass. We request a sensistivity of 0.33 mJy per pointing which in return leads to an estimated total time request of 1.48h for this target inclusing overheads.

We request CO(4-3) observations with Band 3 for a quasar at z=3.043, where the CO line is shifted to an observed frequency of 114.03 GHz. We will use a bandwidth of 1875 MHz in dual polarization mode, which is fully sufficient to detect the CO emission line with an expected width of a few 100 km/s. We set three more spectral windows with the same width for the continuum estimation. We need an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec which is comparable to the resolution in our near-infrared Adaptive Optics supported K-band imaging. To estimate the expected CO flux density, we compute an absolute B-band luminosity of 10^11.4 Lsol from our H-band imaging for a host galaxy of 10^11 Msol. After converting the optical magnitude into a FIR luminosity we predict a total CO flux density of about 1 mJy consistent with the flux densities estimated for z=6 quasar host galaxies in Wang[2013]. We request a sensistivity of 0.2 mJy per pointing which in return leads to an estimated total time request of 1.03h for this target inclusing overheads.

We request [CII] observations with Band 8 for a quasar at z=3.89, where the CII line is shifted to an observed frequency of 388.65 GHz. We will use a bandwidth of 1875 MHz in dual polarization mode, which is fully sufficient to detect the CO emission line with an expected width of a few 100 km/s. We set three more spectral windows with the same width for the continuum estimation. We need a high angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec which is comparable to the expected resolution in our near-infrared Adaptive Optics supported K-band imaging. Since we do not have a stellar mass estimate yet we scale down the flux estimates from Wang[2013] for their quasars with similar properties assuming a line width of 200 km/s. We request a sensistivity of 0.4 mJy per pointing which in return leads to an estimated total time request of 2.71h for this target inclusing overheads.

We request [CII] observations with Band 8 for a quasar at z=3.86, where the CII line is shifted to an observed frequency of 391.05 GHz. We will use a bandwidth of 1875 MHz in dual polarization mode, which is fully sufficient to detect the CO emission line with an expected width of a few 100 km/s. We set three more spectral windows with the same width for the continuum estimation. We need a high angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec which is comparable to the expected resolution in our near-infrared Adaptive Optics supported K-band imaging. Since we do not have a stellar mass estimate yet we scale down the flux estimates from Wang[2013] for their quasars with similar properties assuming a line width of 200 km/s. We request a sensistivity of 0.4 mJy per pointing which in return leads to an estimated total time request of 1.84h for this target inclusing overheads.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose observations of the [CII] fine structure line or the CO(4-3) line emission together with the far-infrared dust continuum of a representative sample of five low luminosity quasar host galaxies at redshift z=3-4. This sample represents the highest possible redshift quasar sample for which we are able to obtain stellar mass estimates from deep high-resolution images using the SUBARU telescope. We aim to estimate the gas mass from the CO emission and more accurate dynamical masses by correcting for inclination effects as well as reliable SFR to complete our picture of BH-galaxy co-evolution at a point only 1.5-2 Gyr after the big bang. We will have a unique sample, with for the first time, full information of the stellar and gas content of the host galaxy. From the specific growth rates we will be able to constrain the formation time scales of the host as well as its potential fate. With black hole masses well below the bulk of bright quasars at these redshift, we can also directly compare our results to low z samples typically covering the same BH mass range and give very strong constraints on a possible redshift evolution of the BH - host galaxy scaling relations.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, The University of Tokyo

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, The University of Tokyo
Institute for Cosmic Ray Research, The University of Tokyo
